title: 108_hr4019
content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Congress recognizes the importance of good health and access to high-quality health information and services for public health improvement. They highlight the benefits of Taiwan's participation in international health cooperation, noting its substantial achievements in the field of health despite not being a member of the World Health Organization. Taiwan's population exceeds that of most WHO member states. Taiwan has achieved significant milestones in health, including high life expectancy, low maternal and infant mortality rates, eradication of infectious diseases like cholera and smallpox, and providing hepatitis B vaccinations to children. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Taiwan's health agencies have collaborated effectively. On January 14, 2001, Taiwan sent rescue teams to El Salvador after a major earthquake, showcasing their willingness to assist in international aid and health activities. On January 14, 2001, Taiwan sent 2 rescue teams to El Salvador after a 7.6-7.9 magnitude earthquake. The teams included 90 individuals with expertise in firefighting, medicine, and civil engineering. Taiwan also donated $200,000 in relief aid to El Salvador. The World Health Assembly has allowed observers from various organizations to participate in its activities, including the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1974 and the United States declared support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations in 1994. In 1994, the United States declared support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations, specifically the WHO. Taiwan's involvement in the WHO can benefit not only its own health system but also the global community. Taiwan's participation in the WHO is supported by various organizations, including the United States. President Bush emphasized the importance of Taiwan's voice being heard in international organizations, even if membership is not possible. Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy also highlighted the need for Taiwan to benefit and contribute to the WHO. In a speech at the World Medical Association, Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced America's support for Taiwan's efforts to gain observership status at the World Health Assembly, emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's public health efforts. Taiwan donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in 2002. In 2003, Taiwan had 84 deaths from SARS. Avian influenza has reemerged in Asia. In December 2002, Taiwan had 84 deaths from SARS and avian influenza reemerged in Asia. The outbreaks highlight the importance of global cooperation in health organizations like the WHO. The importance of global cooperation in health organizations like the WHO is emphasized as the pace of globalization quickens and infectious diseases spread. It is crucial for all people, including those in Taiwan, to have the opportunity to participate in international health organizations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services acknowledged the need for effective public health among all peoples during the 2003 World Health Assembly meeting. The Secretary of State is authorized to initiate a US plan to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva and introduce a resolution in support of observer status. The Secretary of State is directed to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva and introduce a resolution in support of observer status. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress detailing the US plan to obtain observer status for Taiwan at the annual World Health Assembly summit. A report must be submitted to Congress detailing the US plan to obtain observer status for Taiwan at the annual World Health Assembly summit in Geneva, Switzerland. The report should include efforts made to promote Taiwan's bid and steps to endorse and obtain observer status at the next meeting. The House of Representatives passed the resolution on April 21, 2004.
